coredata.dc:title: Average Step Length Estimation Models' Evaluation Using Inertial Sensors: A Review
coredata.dc:publisher: Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers Inc.

abstract.ce:para: Inertial sensors of smartphones and other Internet-of-Things devices present a very promising tool to monitor users' activity including their step length. In this review paper, we deal with an in-depth analysis and comparison of 13 representative step length estimation models using smartphone inertial sensors: step-frequency-based, acceleration-based, angle-based, and multiparameter. Hereby, we have studied the influence of different walking speeds and four typical sensor positions on the models' performance. Results indicate that smartphone position affected the performance of most acceleration-based models derived from a gait model. Their performance deteriorated if smartphone was carried in hand or pocket. Walking speed affected the performance of models that include step frequency when tuned with personalized sets of constants. Most of them performed better for fast and normal walking speeds. During this research, we also established an open-source dataset that contains over 22 km of gait measurements obtained from a group of 15 healthy adults.

xocs:funding-list.xocs:funding-text: Manuscript received June 28, 2018; revised October 10, 2018; accepted October 16, 2018. Date of publication October 30, 2018; date of current version December 21, 2018. The work of M. Vezocˇnik was supported by the University of Ljubljana–2016 Generation. The associate editor coordinating the review of this paper and approving it for publication was Prof. Octavian Postolache. (Corresponding author: Melanija Vezocˇnik.) The authors are with the Faculty of Computer and Information Science, University of Ljubljana, 1000 Ljubljana, Slovenia (e-mail: mv6082@student. uni-lj.si; matjaz.juric@fri.uni-lj.si). Digital Object Identifier 10.1109/JSEN.2018.2878646

item-info.copyright: Copyright 2019 Elsevier B.V., All rights reserved.

abstract.ce:para: Inertial sensors of smartphones and other Internet-of-Things devices present a very promising tool to monitor users' activity including their step length. In this review paper, we deal with an in-depth analysis and comparison of 13 representative step length estimation models using smartphone inertial sensors: step-frequency-based, acceleration-based, angle-based, and multiparameter. Hereby, we have studied the influence of different walking speeds and four typical sensor positions on the models' performance. Results indicate that smartphone position affected the performance of most acceleration-based models derived from a gait model. Their performance deteriorated if smartphone was carried in hand or pocket. Walking speed affected the performance of models that include step frequency when tuned with personalized sets of constants. Most of them performed better for fast and normal walking speeds. During this research, we also established an open-source dataset that contains over 22 km of gait measurements obtained from a group of 15 healthy adults.
